Graduate School of Engineering Nagoya University Nagoya 464-8603 Japan Graphical abstract Alumina-supported gold catalysts (Au/Al2O3) prepared under various conditions were observed on an atomic scale using aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (Cs-STEM). The Au particles, including single Au atoms, on Cs-STEM images were extracted using morphological image-processing, and the size distributions for reaction site candidates, such as the corner, edge, and surface of Au clusters, in a unit weight of Au/Al2O3 catalyst were calculated. Based on the size distributions for these reaction site candidates, we inspected the effective sites and sizes of Au catalysts for the hydrogenation of aldehydes (5-hydroxymethylfurfural and benzaldehyde) and a nitro compound (nitrobenzene). The results suggested that the corner atoms are a key site for the hydrogenation of aldehydes and the nitro compound because the dissociative adsorption of H2 on corner atoms controls the reaction rate. Meanwhile, the effective size for the aldehydes was smaller than that for the nitro compound due to their different adsorption sites: while the aldehydes are adsorbed on the corners of Au clusters, the nitro group is adsorbed on their edges. The adsorption of the reactants was supported by reaction kinetics and X-ray absorption spectroscopy analyses. The specific active size for hydrogenation reactions was also investigated based on the size distributions. Keywords Gold cluster Cs-corrected STEM Structural effect Hydrogenation 1 Introduction Supported Au nanoparticles have been intensively studied not only because they provide unique catalytic activities for various reactions, but also because their catalytic effect is often size-dependent [1–3]. It is well known that Au nanoparticles show high catalytic activity for the CO oxidation reaction [1–3]. The catalytic activity drastically increases when the particle size decreases to below 3nm. Such a unique size effect can also be observed in the hydrogenation reaction, where Au catalysts often show unique selectivity that is not observed with Pt group metal catalysts [3–9]. For example, unsaturated aldehydes and nitro compounds are selectively hydrogenated to the corresponding alcohols and amines on supported Au catalysts due to their preferential adsorption of aldehydes and nitro groups compared to a CC group [4–11]. In hydrogenation reactions on Au catalysts, the activation of H2 is a key step [12–14]. It has been demonstrated that H2 is dissociatively adsorbed on low-coordinated Au atoms on the corners or edges of Au nanoparticles, while H2 is not adsorbed on a clean Au surface with the properties of bulk Au [15,16]. Furthermore, the dissociative adsorption of H2 has been suggested to occur at the interface between Au nanoparticles and metal oxide supports such as Al2O3 [13,17]. Au3+ has also been proposed to be the active species for the hydrogenation reaction on Au/MgO [18]. The Au active site, size, and species for the hydrogenation reaction are still not clear. Meanwhile, techniques for particle structure (size and shape) analysis and nanomaterial synthesis have recently been developed, and, accordingly, the catalytic activities of Au cluster catalysts with diameters of less than 2nm have been explored [19–24]. Such small Au clusters can show extraordinary catalytic activity based on their unique structures and electronic state, and the catalytic activity can vary according to differences at the atomic scale [3,25]. Therefore, the size effect of Au clusters has attracted intense attention. Atomic-scale observation using aberration-corrected (scanning) transmission electron microscopy (Cs-(S)TEM) is a powerful technique for investigating the size-dependent catalytic activity of Au clusters [19,20,26,27]. A pioneering study on the Au cluster size effect using Cs-STEM by Herzing et al. demonstrated that a Au cluster of ∼10atoms with a bilayer structure has high catalytic activity for CO oxidation [19]. Very recently, Corma et al. showed that Au clusters of 5–10 atoms are extremely active for the oxidation of thiophenol [20]. Interestingly, both of these studies indicated that single Au atoms have little or no catalytic activity, while tiny clusters are specifically active. Cs-(S)TEM can also provide more structural information than just the particle size, since it can be used to visualize the atomic alignment in a metal cluster [28–30]. Akita et al. used Cs-TEM for a detailed investigation of the interface between Au clusters and their supports, which can play a critical role in their catalytic activities [28]. Long et al. and Sanchez et al. used Cs-(S)TEM to reveal the crystallinity of supported metal clusters [29,30]. They clarified that the crystallinity of metal clusters varies according to their size, metal–support interaction, and the nature of the metal. Our recent study on the use of a Ru catalyst for the hydrogen oxidation reaction showed that size-dependent crystallinity significantly affected the catalytic performance [31]. Therefore, Cs-STEM analysis can provide new and detailed structural information, which should promote our understanding of the structure-dependent catalytic activities of supported metal clusters, and could lead to the development of highly active catalysts for industrial applications. When Cs-STEM is used to observe supported metal catalysts, we can observe all of the supported metal species, from single metal atoms to nanoparticles (if the metal species shows high contrast against the support) [19,20,26,32–36]. Thus, if we can evaluate the particle size of all of the supported metal species on STEM images, we can obtain a quantitative size distribution for the number of metal particles, and then can estimate the number of Au atoms at potential reaction sites, such as the corners, edges, and surface of metal particles. Such a particle size distribution analysis may be used to elucidate the active site and effective size of metal catalysts. To obtain more realistic size distributions based on atomic-scale observation, we have developed a new automatic STEM image-processing method that uses a mathematical morphological operation (Fig. 1 ) [32]. We demonstrated that this morphological image-processing method extracts supported Au particles (Au/Al2O3) more accurately (i.e., with fewer artifacts) than conventional image-processing methods. Furthermore, the morphological operation can connect atoms in an Au cluster showing the atomic structure on a STEM image, and allow us to evaluate the cluster size. Therefore, we successfully evaluated the sizes of all Au particles, including single Au atoms, on STEM images using morphological image-processing. On the other hand, we previously reported the selective hydrogenation of an aldehyde compound, hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), on supported Au catalysts [37]. The hydrogenation activity of a supported Au catalyst depended on its size, and small Au clusters showed high catalytic activity for hydrogenation. In the present paper, we investigated the effective sites and sizes of Au/Al2O3 for the hydrogenation of aldehydes and a nitro compound based on a size-distribution analysis on an atomic scale. While the key sites of Au particles for hydrogenation of the aldehyde and nitro compounds were the same, interestingly, the aldehyde and nitro compounds were associated with different active sizes. To elucidate the origin of this difference in the size effect, we analyzed the adsorption of these compounds on Au particles using Au L3 edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Al2O3 (JRC-ALO-5) was provided by the Catalysis Society of Japan. Al2O3 contains 0.68% Fe2O3, 0.02% SiO2, 0.21% Cl by weight, and a trace amount of SO4 as impurities. HMF, benzaldehyde (BA), and nitrobenzene (NB) were obtained from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. Other reagents were purchased from Kishida Chemical Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalysts Au/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by a deposition precipitation method. Al2O3 was ground and meshed to 22–75μm. To a suspension of Al2O3 (0.40g) in HAuCl4 aq. (1.03mM, 20mL) was added NaOH aq. (0.10M) to adjust the pH to 7.0 at room temperature. The suspension was warmed at 343K under stirring for 1h. The solid was separated by centrifugation and washed five times with 30mL of distilled water. After the wash water was removed, the slurry was dried at 363K for 8h. The resulting powder was treated at 473, 573, 623, and 673K under H2 and at 773K under air for 4h to obtain various Au/Al2O3 catalysts. The Au loading as evaluated by a sequential inductively-coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer (Thermo Jarrel Ash IRIS/AP) was 0.83wt%. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The hydrogenation of HMF, BA, and NB was carried out using a stainless autoclave with gas in- and outlets (30mL, Taiatsu Techno Co., TVS-1 type). To the autoclave were added Au/Al2O3 (10mg) and an aqueous solution of HMF (0.10M of HMF with 0.10M of dioxan as an internal standard, 2.0mL), a toluene solution of BA (molar ratio of BA:o-xylene (internal standard):toluene=1.0:1.0:98.0, 2.0mL), or a toluene solution of NB (molar ratio of NB:o-xylene:toluene=8.5:1.0:90.5, 2mL). The hydrogenation of HMF, BA, and NB was conducted under 5.5MPa of H2 at 393K, 3.0MPa of H2 at 373K, and 6.0MPa of H2 at 393K. The reaction solutions were analyzed by a gas chromatograph (SHIMADZU GC-14A) equipped with FID using an Ultra ALLOY+-5 capillary column (Frontier Laboratories Ltd.) to determine the reactant conversions and product yields. The initial reaction rate was evaluated at a reactant conversion of less than 30%, where the corresponding alcohols or amine were obtained without any hydrogenation of their CC bonds. Preparation of the catalyst and the hydrogenation of BA and NB were performed three times to determine the experimental error. 2.4 TEM observation and image processing TEM samples were prepared by depositing drops of methanol suspensions of the Au/Al2O3 catalysts on carbon-coated Cu grids (Okenshoji Co. Ltd.). High angle annular dark field (HAADF) STEM images of the Au/Al2O3 catalysts were obtained on a JEOL-ARM200F operated at 200kV. Images of Au/Al2O3 prepared at 473, 573, 623, and 673K were obtained at a magnification of 5M with 2048×2048pixels or at 10M with 1024×1024pixels (these give an identical length per pixel ratio), and images of Au/Al2O3 prepared at 773K were obtained at a magnification of 2.5M with 2048×2048pixels, where single Au atoms could be distinguished. The images were processed by a morphological operation using MATLAB (Mathworks Inc.) as reported previously [32]. A typical image-processing procedure is shown in Fig. 1. A raw image of Au/Al2O3 (Fig. 1(a)) was smoothed using a convolution filter to reduce quantum and electrical noise (Fig. 1(b)). A background image was prepared from the smoothed image by a morphological opening operation using a disk larger than a Au atom (Fig. 1(c)). The background image was subtracted from the smoothed image (Fig. 1(d)). The contrast of the background-subtracted image was changed by using a threshold, and transformed to a binary image (Fig. 1(e)). Any remaining noise (less than the electron probe size) on the binary image was removed by another morphological opening operation (Fig. 1(f)). Au atoms in clusters on the resulting binary image were connected by a morphological closing operation on the basis of the atomic diameter of Au (0.288nm) (Fig. 1(g)). The shapes of Au particles were corrected by a dilation operation that took into account the sizes of the electron probe and the Au atom (Fig. 1(h)). If the final image had artifacts derived from, for example, the large thickness of the Al2O3 support, they were eliminated to evaluate only Au particles. The size of a Au particle was determined as a circle with the same area as the particles in the processed image. The error in particle size arising from particle extraction was estimated to be ±0.07nm, which is the probe size of Cs-STEM (evaluated particle size ±0.07nm) [32]. Since Cs-STEM has an atomic resolution, we evaluated the size distribution with almost the same size interval as an Au atom, 0.3nm (Fig. 2 ). The number of particles counted was ca. 500–4000 (Table S1). Our statistical analysis suggested that a particle count of ca. 500 should provide reasonable statistics (Fig. S1 and Table S2). The error bars in Fig. 2 were derived from the above-described error in the particle-size analysis (evaluated particle size±0.07nm). The number of Au atoms in a Au particle and the number of Au atoms on a corner, edge, and surface were calculated assuming two particle-structure models, i.e., half-cut cuboctahedral and truncated cuboctahedral structures (Fig. 3 ) [38,39]. (For detailed information on how to determine the numbers of Au atoms, see the Supporting Information Figs. S2–S10.) In previous studies, similar to or the same models as those shown in Fig. 3 were used to investigate the active site and size effect of supported Au particles showing a faceted structure [38,39]. We actually observed half-cut and faceted structures for Au clusters (Figs. S11 and S12). It has been reported that a faceted structure is maintained under a reductive atmosphere, but can change to a rounded structure under an oxidative atmosphere [40,41]. In the present study, we investigated the catalytic activity of Au/Al2O3 for hydrogenation (reductive atmosphere), and thus, the faceted structure is considered to be maintained during hydrogenation [41]. Fig. 4 shows the average numbers of Au atoms and particles calculated using the two model structures. (Figs. S13 and S14 show the size distributions calculated on the assumption of cuboctahedral and truncated cuboctahedral structures, respectively.) The error bar in Fig. 4 was derived from the difference in the two model structures and the above-mentioned error in the particle-size evaluation. The following paragraph explains how we derived the number of Au atoms and particles in a unit weight of Au/Al2O3 catalyst. To obtain Fig. 4, we first calculated the number of Au atoms in each counted Au particle on STEM images using the model structures shown in Fig. 3 (Figs. S2–S4). Here, particles with diameters of less than 0.3nm were regarded as single Au atoms. The total number of Au atoms was then calculated: Σni , where ni is the mole number of Au atoms in a Au particle i. The total number of Au atoms on STEM images was normalized to the number of Au atoms in a unit weight of the Au/Al2O3 catalyst (42μmol of Au atoms in 1g of Au/Al2O3 with Au loading of 0.83wt%) to obtain the size distribution for the number of Au atoms in particles in a unit weight of Au/Al2O3 (Fig. 4(a)). By using the ratio of the number of Au atoms in a unit weight (42μmol) to that on STEM images (Σni ), i.e., 42/Σni , we converted the size distribution for the counted Au particle number (Fig. 2) to that in a unit weight of the Au/Al2O3 catalyst shown in Fig. 4(b): the number of Au particles in a unit weight of the catalyst was calculated using the above ratio of 42/Σni : (Nc /NA )×(42/Σni ), where Nc is the number of Au particles counted on the STEM image (Fig. 2), and NA is Avogadro’s number. The numbers of Au atoms on the corners, edges, and surface of Au particles were also calculated on the assumption that Au particles have half-cut cuboctahedral and truncated cuboctahedral structures (Figs. S5–S10). The numbers of Au atoms on the corners, edges, and surface of Au particles were weighted by the above factor, 42/Σni , and converted to those in a unit weight of Au/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 4(c–e)). 2.5 Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy FT-IR spectra were recorded on a JASCO FT/IR-6100 (JASCO Co.) with a resolution of 4cm−1. A supported Au catalyst (20mg) was pressed into a wafer with a diameter of 20mm. The wafer was pretreated under Ar flow (100mLmin−1) at 473K for 1h, and then exposed to BA and NB vapor (2.0μL in liquid) under Ar flow (100mLmin−1) at 423K. After 10min, the FT-IR spectra were obtained. Next, samples were held under a flow of 100mLmin−1 of H2 at 423K for 60 or 3min, and FT-IR spectra were obtained again. 2.6 X-ray absorption spectroscopy Au L3 edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy measurement was carried out on the BL5S1 beamline of the Aichi Synchrotron Radiation Research Center with a Si(111) two-crystal monochromator (1.2GeV, 300mA). The X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra of the Au/Al2O3 catalysts and those immersed in liquids of BA and NB were recorded in fluorescence mode using a Lytle detector with a Ga filter. Data reduction was performed using the program REX2000 Ver. 2.5.9 (Rigaku Co.). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Size-dependent hydrogenation activity Typical HAADF STEM images and Au particle-size distributions for the counted particle number of the Au/Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 2. The HAADF STEM observation for Cs-corrected STEM and the particle-size analysis using our morphological image-processing method revealed that there are many single Au atoms and small clusters that cannot be detected by conventional non-Cs-corrected TEM. The fraction of single atoms (0–0.3nm) in the distribution is quite large. The large fraction of single Au atoms is not due to impurities of Al2O3 or artifacts on the STEM images because Al2O3 does not contain heavy metals such as Au (the contrast in the HAADF STEM image is proportional to the square of the atomic number (Z)) and also because artifacts on the images are removed by the morphological operation. Furthermore, this result is supported by previous studies with Au species on a thin alumina layer, which demonstrated that single Au atoms can be stabilized by AuAl interaction [42,43]. Therefore, based on the atomic-scale observation using Cs-TEM, we obtained realistic histograms, including single Au atoms, which is much different from conventional histograms obtained by conventional TEM. The shape of the size distribution gradually changed from 473K to 673K, and the frequency of Au particles of 1–2nm increased. The size distribution varied greatly under treatment at 773K, and larger particles were observed. This behavior can be explained by the fact that the melting point of Au nanoparticles depends on their size [44,45]. The average particle sizes of the Au/Al2O3 catalysts were evaluated from the size distributions in Fig. 2: ΣDi /NT , where Di is the size of an Au particle i, and NT is the total counted number of Au particles (Table S1). The average particle sizes of Au/Al2O3 prepared at 473, 573, 623, 673, and 773K were 0.38, 0.46, 0.56, 0.69, and 1.56nm, respectively. The chemical state of Au/Al2O3 was characterized using XANES spectroscopy, as shown in Fig. 5 . In comparison with the reference spectrum of Au foil, all of the Au/Al2O3 catalysts showed a smaller X-ray adsorption intensity at around 11920eV (so-called white line). Since the white line intensity increases when Au is in more oxidized state, all of the Au/Al2O3 catalysts are more electron-rich than Au foil [46]. This result is consistent with a previous study [47]. The electron-rich Au clusters on Al2O3 are considered to be due to a charge redistribution between Au and Al2O3, more specifically, the transfer of a negative charge from Al2O3 to Au [30,42,43,47]. Fig. 6 (a) shows plots of the reaction rate for hydrogenation of the aldehydes (BA and HMF) against the average particle size. Almost identical size-dependence was observed for the hydrogenation of BA and HMF. The reaction rates increased with a decrease in the average particle size, and reached a maximum at ca. 0.4nm. These results suggest that small Au particles have high catalytic activity for hydrogenation of the aldehydes, but Au particles that are too small are not highly active for these reactions. In fact, our previous study using Au/Al2O3 indicated that single Au atoms are either not active or much less active for the hydrogenation of aldehyde in comparison with Au clusters [37]. Previous reports on Au catalysts for oxidation reactions also demonstrated that single Au atoms are catalytically inactive [19,20]. On the other hand, a previous study on the hydrogenation reaction using Au/MgO proposed that Au3+ is an active species [18]. However, the above XANES analysis indicated that the Au/Al2O3 catalysts are more anionic than Au foil due to the interaction between Au and Al2O3. Therefore, in this study, small Au metal clusters are highly active for hydrogenation of the aldehydes. Fig. 6(b) shows the size effect on the reaction rate for the hydrogenation of NB. Interestingly, the size-dependence for NB was different from that for the aldehydes. This difference in size-dependency suggests that the effective size for NB hydrogenation is larger than that for the aldehydes. Therefore, the size effect on hydrogenation activity varies with the reactants, and more specifically with functional groups. 3.2 Active site for H2 activation The Cs-STEM analysis allowed us to observe all Au species, including single Au atoms, and the morphological image-processing enabled us to evaluate the sizes of all Au species on the Cs-STEM images. This means that the particle-size analysis data provide quantitative information regarding Au particles and atoms. Based on this concept, we converted the number of counted Au particles into the number of Au atoms at potential reaction sites of Au clusters in a unit weight of the Au/Al2O3 catalysts, described in the Section 2. The calculated size distributions for the possible reaction sites (corner, edge, and surface) in a unit weight of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 4(c–e). Based on the calculated size distributions for the potential reaction sites (Fig. 4(c–e)), we investigated the effective site of Au particles for the hydrogenation reactions. Here, we assumed that the catalytic activity of the reaction sites does not change according to the particle size, since the catalytic activity of Au catalysts is considered to be (mainly) determined by the number of active sites [17,48]. (Size-specific activity will be discussed later in this paper.) Our previous study [37] and Fig. 6 suggested that single Au atoms are not active for the hydrogenation reactions. Therefore, we explored the relation between the reaction rates and the number of Au atoms on the potential reaction sites of Au particles with diameters of >0.3nm, i.e., Au clusters (Figs. S20–S27). Fig. 7 shows a plot of the reaction rate for the hydrogenation of BA and HMF against the total number of Au atoms on the (a) corners, (b) edges, and (c) surface of Au clusters (Figs. S20–23). As a result, the plot against the number of corner atoms (Fig. 7(a)) showed the best proportionality among the three plots. This result suggests that the corner of Au clusters is the key site for hydrogenation of the aldehydes. It has been reported that the dissociation of H2 is the rate-determining step for hydrogenation of an aldehyde [14]. Therefore, we concluded that the dissociative adsorption of H2 occurred on the corner atoms of Au clusters. This conclusion is in agreement with previous studies which have indicated that H2 is adsorbed on low-coordinated sites of Au clusters, such as the corners and edges [7,15,16,49,50]. In addition, note that the present study provided deeper insight into H2 adsorption, in that H2 adsorption mainly involves corner atoms. The active site of Au catalysts for the hydrogenation of NB was investigated in the same way as the site for hydrogenation of the aldehydes (Figs. S24–27). Fig. 8 shows plots of the reaction rate for the hydrogenation of NB against the number of corner atoms. The plot against the number of corner atoms on Au clusters sized >0.3nm did not show a good proportional relationship. However, the proportionality was improved by reducing the size range from >0.3nm to >1.2nm, and the plots against the corner atoms on Au clusters sized >0.9 and >1.2nm exhibited a good proportional relationship. On the other hand, the plots against edge and surface atoms did not show such a good proportional relationship (Figs. S26 and S27). Therefore, the corner atoms of Au clusters sized >0.9–1.2nm are considered to play an active role in the hydrogenation of NB. Note that the corner atoms of Au clusters are the active site for the hydrogenation of both NB and the aldehydes. As is the case with the hydrogenation of aldehydes, it has been reported that the dissociation of H2 is a rate-determining step for the hydrogenation of nitro compounds on an Au catalyst [9,12,13]. Thus, we concluded that the dissociative adsorption of H2 on the corner atoms of Au clusters is important for the hydrogenation of NB, as with that of the aldehydes. However, the size range of Au clusters is different between the hydrogenation of NB and that of the aldehydes. While the corner atoms of Au clusters sized >0.9–1.2nm are effective for the hydrogenation of NB, those sized >0.3nm are effective for hydrogenation of the aldehydes. This result indicates that the active cluster size for NB is larger than that for the aldehydes, which is consistent with the results of the investigation regarding average size-dependent catalytic activity (Fig. 6). The difference in the effective size for hydrogenation of the aldehydes and NB can be explained by a difference in adsorption on Au clusters between the aldehydes and NB, which is investigated in the next section. 3.3 Adsorption of aldehyde and nitro compounds Fig. 9 (a) shows a FT-IR spectrum of BA on Au/Al2O3. The spectrum is almost the same as that on Al2O3, as shown in Fig. 9(b). This means that the IR spectrum of BA on Au/Al2O3 is derived from BA on the Al2O3 support. Accordingly, the adsorption of BA on Au species cannot be analyzed by IR spectroscopy because the spectrum of BA on Al2O3 veils that of BA on Au species [51]. We also checked the IR spectrum of BA adsorbed on Au/Al2O3 under a H2 flow at 423K, as exhibited in Fig. 9(c). The IR spectrum of BA was almost independent of the H2 flow, although previous studies demonstrated that BA is hydrogenated under similar conditions [52,53]. This result implies that BA adsorbed on Au species is reactive for hydrogenation, while that on an Al2O3 support is not. To examine the adsorption of BA on Au species, we used X-ray absorption spectroscopy [15,16,51,54,55]. Fig. 10 shows Au L3 edge XANES spectra of Al2O3 prepared at 473K and that with BA. The XANES spectrum of Au/Al2O3 with BA showed greater X-ray absorption just above the edge (at 11,910–11,950eV) compared to that without BA. The XANES spectra of the other Au/Al2O3 catalysts also showed an increase in X-ray absorption intensity in the presence of BA (Fig. S28). It has been reported that the adsorption of molecules such as H2 and thiols on Au nanoparticles can increase the Au L3 edge X-ray absorption intensity just above the edge due to the electronic transition to AuH and AuS bonds, i.e., AuH and AuS scattering [15,16,55]. Similarly, in the BA adsorption in this study, the formation of a bond between Au and CO of an aldehyde group [56–59] should increase the X-ray absorption. Fig. 11 shows the difference XANES spectra between Au/Al2O3 catalysts with and without BA. Fig. 12 shows the area of the difference spectra at 11,905–11,950eV plotted against the particle size. The plot in Fig. 12 has a shape similar to the plot for the reaction rate of BA in Fig. 6. In fact, the area of the difference spectra showed a proportional relationship with the reaction rate for BA, and accordingly a proportional relationship with the number of corner atoms of Au clusters, as presented in Fig. 13 . The X-ray absorption intensity due to the scattering between Au and adsorbed atoms is known to increase with the amount of adsorbate [15,16,54,55]. Therefore, we concluded that BA is adsorbed on the corner atoms of Au clusters, which is the same site as for the activation of H2. The dependence of the reaction rate on the concentration of BA was also investigated (Fig. S29). As a result, an increase in the BA concentration decreased the reaction rate. These results suggest that BA is strongly adsorbed on the corner atoms of Au clusters where H2 is also adsorbed. Fig. 14 (a) and (b) shows FT-IR spectra of NB adsorbed on Au/Al2O3 and Al2O3, respectively. The two spectra were almost identical. Thus, as is the case with BA, NB adsorption on Au species cannot be analyzed by IR spectroscopy due to the adsorption of NB on the Al2O3 support. The FT-IR spectrum of NB on Au/Al2O3 changed under a H2 flow at 423K for 3min, and the spectrum in Fig. 14(c) indicated the formation of aniline [13]. This behavior is different from that in the case of BA, for which the IR spectrum was not changed by the H2 flow (Fig. 9). NB would move on the Al2O3 support and be hydrogenated by association with H2 activated on Au clusters. Fig. 15 (a) shows the Au L3 edge XANES spectra of Au/Al2O3 prepared at 473K with and without NB. The XANES spectrum did not change in the presence of NB, reflected by the difference spectrum shown in Fig. 15(b). The XANES spectrum of other Au catalysts with larger particle sizes also did not change in the presence of NB (Fig. S30). This result suggests that NB is not fixed on Au clusters. On the other hand, previous studies have demonstrated that a nitro compound can be adsorbed at the interface between a Au cluster and a metal oxide support through the oxygen atoms of its nitro group [10]. Thus, it is reasonable to consider that NB is not fixed at a distinct position relative to an Au atom in a cluster due to the weak adsorption of NB on Au and its thermal fluctuation [60]. Furthermore, as noted above, IR spectroscopy detected NB on Au/Al2O3 (Fig. 14). It is likely that NB is adsorbed much more weakly on Au species than on Al2O3. On the other hand, the adsorption of NB on Au clusters was also investigated in terms of the dependence of the reaction rate on the concentration of NB (Fig. S29). An increase in the NB concentration did not decrease the reaction rate. This result suggests that NB does not disturb the adsorption of H2 on Au clusters, and NB is much more weakly adsorbed on Au in comparison with BA. Previously, Boronat et al. reported the adsorption of a nitro compound on Au/TiO2 [10]. They demonstrated that the interface between the support and an Au cluster is a unique adsorption site for a nitro compound to be hydrogenated. The energy for the adsorption of a nitro compound at the interface is greater than that on a Au surface but smaller than that on the support. Therefore, it is reasonable to consider that NB at the interface between Au clusters and Al2O3 is hydrogenated by the dissociatively adsorbed hydrogen on the corner atoms. More specifically, we considered that the interface formed on the edges of Au clusters is effective for NB adsorption, since NB adsorption at the interface between the edges of Au clusters and Al2O3 would not disturb the adsorption of H2 on the corners of a Au cluster. Based on the above results, we created models for the adsorption of BA and NB as well as H2 on Au clusters, as shown in Fig. 16 . In the figure, H2 is heterogeneously dissociated on a corner of an Au cluster and Al2O3 [13,17]. BA is adsorbed at the corner of an Au cluster in competition with H2 (Fig. 16(a)). On the other hand, NB is adsorbed at the interface between the edge of a Au cluster and Al2O3, without disturbing the adsorption of H2 on the corner of the Au cluster (Fig. 16(b)). Note that an edge is formed when Au clusters reach a certain size: >0.79nm in the case of the cuboctahedral model and >1.15nm in the case of the truncated cuboctahedral model (Figs. 3 and S2). The necessity of edge atoms for NB adsorption may be why the effective size for NB hydrogenation is larger than that for BA hydrogenation. 3.4 Size-specifically high catalytic activity The aforesaid demonstrated that the number of corner atoms of Au clusters determines the reaction rates. On the other hand, several recent studies on Au clusters have demonstrated that Au clusters with a specific size have high catalytic activity [19–23,61]. We tried to understand the size-specific catalytic activity of Au/Al2O3 for the hydrogenation reactions based on the results of a size-distribution analysis, assuming that all corner sites are the same is loosened. We investigated the correlation between the reaction rates and the number of corner atoms within each of the 0.3nm intervals shown in Fig. 4(c). As a result, a good proportional correlation was observed in the case of Au clusters with diameters of 0.6–0.9nm and 0.9–1.2nm, as shown in Fig. 17 (Fig. S31). Au clusters sized 0.6–1.2nm may have higher catalytic activity for the hydrogenation reaction in comparison with smaller or larger clusters. To explore the origin of the size-specifically high catalytic activity of Au clusters of 0.6–1.2nm, we closely examined the size-dependent structure of Au clusters using Cs-STEM. Fig. 18 shows STEM images of Au clusters sized (a) 0.3–0.6, (b) 0.6–0.9, and (c) 0.9–1.2nm. Au clusters of 0.3–0.6nm in Fig. 18(a), which are composed of a few Au atoms, exhibited a monolayer structure, i.e., a 1D or 2D structure, on STEM images. This structure is well consistent with previous studies that presented 1D or 2D clusters composed of some Au atoms on a thin film of alumina [42,43]. The 1D or 2D morphology of the Au clusters of 0.3–0.6nm can cause low catalytic activity [19,25,62,63]. Actually, previous studies on the activity of a supported Au catalyst for CO oxidation indicated that a Au monolayer is not highly active [19,25,62,63]. For Au clusters of 0.6–0.9nm, although some Au clusters (left image in Fig. 18(b)) also showed a 2D structure, others showed packed Au atoms, suggesting the formation of a 3D (bilayer or more than bilayer) structure (center and right images in Fig. 18(b)). Most of the Au clusters of >0.9nm appeared to have a 3D structure (Fig. 18(c)). In addition, the model Au clusters (Fig. S2) have bi- or more layered structure when the size is larger than 0.8nm. Therefore, as Au clusters grow from 0.6nm to 1.2nm, their structures change from 2D to 3D (Fig. 18). Previous studies have demonstrated that a Au cluster at a size at which the structure changes from 2D to 3D provides high catalytic activity [19,25,62,63]. The size range (0.6–1.2nm) that was associated with a bilayer structure for Au clusters is in agreement with a previous study of Au clusters supported on iron oxide [19]. Au clusters of 0.6–1.2nm show a disordered arrangement of Au atoms in a cluster. This is considered to be due to the noncrystalline-to-crystalline phase transition depending on the size and the kind of support [30]. The disordered structure might also be responsible for the high catalytic activity [7,64]. Therefore, the size-dependent layered structure and the crystallinity can be responsible for the size-specific catalytic activity of Au clusters of 0.6–1.2nm. The active size for the hydrogenation of NB was also investigated in the same way as that for hydrogenation of the aldehydes. As a result, Au clusters of 1.5–1.8nm were proportionally correlated with the reaction rate for NB hydrogenation, as shown in Fig. 19 , in comparison with Au clusters in the other size ranges (Fig. S32). (The proportionality of the plot in Fig. 19 is not very good, but the proportional line is within the error range.) This result implies that Au clusters of 1.5–1.8nm are highly active compared to the other Au clusters. The highly active cluster size for NB (1.5–1.8nm) is larger than that for the aldehydes (0.6–1.2nm). This is consistent with the above result regarding the average size-dependent catalytic activity (Fig. 6). For the hydrogenation of NB, the effective size of Au clusters is larger than that for hydrogenation of the aldehydes, since the edge atoms of Au clusters are needed for adsorption sites of NB. In fact, Au clusters of 1.5–1.8nm exhibited one or two edge atoms, as shown in Fig. 20 . Meanwhile, in terms of the layered structure, Au clusters of 1.5–1.8nm have a 3D structure according to the above observation (Fig. 18). It has been reported that an increase in Au cluster size causes an increase in the number of layers and a decrease in catalytic activity [62,63]. Thus, the high catalytic activity of Au clusters sized 1.5–1.8nm is considered to be due to their low number of layers (>monolayer) and edge atoms for efficient H2 activation and NB adsorption. 4 Conclusion We analyzed the sizes of various Au/Al2O3 catalysts using Cs-STEM and morphological image-processing, and determined the size distribution at an atomic scale. Using this size distribution, we calculated the number of potential reaction sites in a unit weight of the Au/Al2O3 catalysts. The size distributions for the potential reaction sites allowed us to inspect the active sites and sizes of Au particles for the hydrogenation of aldehydes (BA and HMF) and a nitro compound (NB). The results indicated that the corner atoms are effective reaction sites for both hydrogenations because the dissociative adsorption of H2 on corner atoms is a key step in the hydrogenation reactions. However, the effective size is different between the aldehydes and NB; more specifically, the effective size for hydrogenation of the aldehydes is smaller than that for the hydrogenation of NB. To elucidate the origin of this variation in the effective particle size with functional compounds, the adsorption of BA and NB on Au clusters was investigated using FT-IR spectroscopy, XANES spectroscopy, and a reaction kinetics analysis. The corner atoms of a Au metal cluster are active for the adsorption of both BA and H2. On the other hand, NB interacts with Au clusters much more weakly than BA. NB at the interface between Au edge atoms and Al2O3 is thought to be hydrogenated. Thus, for the hydrogenation of NB, edge atoms are necessary for NB adsorption while corner atoms are necessary for H2 adsorption. This can explain why the effective Au cluster size for NB hydrogenation is larger than that for the aldehydes. The effective size was examined more deeply based on the size distributions at an atomic scale. The results suggested that Au clusters of 0.6–1.2nm show high activity for hydrogenation of the aldehydes, and Au clusters of 1.5–1.8nm show high activity for hydrogenation of the nitro compound. The origin of the different activities of specific sizes for hydrogenation was explained in terms of the size-dependent structure, i.e., a layered structure, crystallinity, and the generation of edge atoms at a certain size. Our study demonstrated that a size-distribution analysis at an atomic scale can provide a better understanding of the structure-dependent catalytic activity of supported Au catalysts. Furthermore, we also found that XANES analysis is useful for evaluating adsorption of the reactants on Au particles. These techniques can be applied to other metal catalysts, and should contribute to our understanding of the structure-dependent activity of supported metal catalysts, which is one of the essential objectives of heterogeneous catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Alumina-supported gold catalysts (Au/Al2O3) prepared under various conditions were observed on an atomic scale using aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (Cs-STEM). The Au particles, including single Au atoms, on Cs-STEM images were extracted using morphological image-processing, and the size distributions for reaction site candidates, such as the corner, edge, and surface of Au clusters, in a unit weight of Au/Al2O3 catalyst were calculated. Based on the size distributions for these reaction site candidates, we inspected the effective sites and sizes of Au catalysts for the hydrogenation of aldehydes (5-hydroxymethylfurfural and benzaldehyde) and a nitro compound (nitrobenzene). The results suggested that the corner atoms are a key site for the hydrogenation of aldehydes and the nitro compound because the dissociative adsorption of H2 on corner atoms controls the reaction rate. Meanwhile, the effective size for the aldehydes was smaller than that for the nitro compound due to their different adsorption sites: while the aldehydes are adsorbed on the corners of Au clusters, the nitro group is adsorbed on their edges. The adsorption of the reactants was supported by reaction kinetics and X-ray absorption spectroscopy analyses. The specific active size for hydrogenation reactions was also investigated based on the size distributions.
coredata.dc:title: Atomic-scale insight into the structural effect of a supported Au catalyst based on a size-distribution analysis using Cs-STEM and morphological image-processing
